metadata.subject: The case for naming a U.S. secretary of Culture

relationships.description: Music critic making policy recommendations to the President
Instigated petition for cultural ministry to Obama

emotional_indicators: frustration with political neglect of arts
analysis.purpose: To advocate for creation of a Cabinet-level Secretary of Culture position in the U.S. government
analysis.significance: Proposes significant government restructuring to elevate arts and humanities to Cabinet-level status

notable_quotes: "The arts and the humanities help us figure out who we are."
"investment in the arts is a more reliable jobs creator than in nearly all industries, nor is it easily outsourced."
"As artists know and politicians refuse to acknowledge, all you have to do to create change is change your mind."

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion present

illegal_activity.description: Document is a policy opinion piece with no illegal activity discussed

details: Article published by Los Angeles Times
References to media coverage and public discourse
Mentions of political debates and public petitions

public_knowledge.context: Policy discussion about government structure and arts funding that was published in major newspaper

analysis.summary: This Los Angeles Times opinion piece by music critic Mark Swed advocates for creating a U.S. Secretary of Culture cabinet position, arguing that arts investment creates jobs and helps define national identity, while proposing specific candidates like Peter Sellars and Leon Botstein for the role.
